repository.corpname: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

did.abstract: The records consist of administrative, financial, and real estate documents associated with the Providence & Worcestor Railroad, a railroad in eastern Connecticut, Rhode Island, and southern Massachusetts, founded in 1844 and leased by the New York & New England Railroad and subsequently the New Haven Railroad in the late 19th century. The company was part of the transfer of railroads to Penn Central in 1969 but resumed running as an independent line in 1973. The records also include small sets of records of the Norwich & Worcester Railroad, the Moshassuck Valley Railroad and the American Short Line Association.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item description, #:#], Providence & Worcester Railroad Records. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of materials pertaining to the railroads of southern New England. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the Reading Room desk.

acqinfo.head: Provenance and Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The records were donated by the Providence & Worcester Railroad prior to 1997.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Copyright Information
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open and available for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The records consist of administrative, financial, and real estate documents associated with the Providence & Worcestor Railroad in its early phase prior to it being leased and absorbed by the New York & New England Railroad and the New Haven Railroad, through the 20th century while under lease to the New Haven Railroad, and the time after 1973 when it separated from Penn Central and resumed running as an independent rail line. The records also include small sets of records of the Norwich & Worcester Railroad, the Moshassuck Valley Railroad and the American Short Line Association.

Series I consists of records of the Providence & Worcestor Railroad generated while it was an independent railroad in the 19th century and includes many documents associated with the railroad line even after it was leased by the New York & New England Railroad and the New Haven Railroad. The records include correspondence and bonds of the President's Office, correspondence, accounts, cash books, cash balance ledgers, lists of stockholders and dividends ledgers of the Treasurer's Office, and letters and reports generated by the Superindendent's Office.
Series II consists of records mostly generated after the company became independent in 1973, consisting of stockholder's documents and stock transfer journals.

Series III holds records associated with the Norwich & Worcestor Railroad representing the company throughout its history, and consist of President's Office records, stockholder reports and correspondence, and information about accidents, agreements, insurance, patents, by-laws, mortgages, and other topics.
Series IV has a small number of records of the Moshassuck Valley Railroad after it was absorbed into the Providence & Worcester Railroad.

Series V consists of documents generated by the Providence & Worcester Railroad's connection to the American Short Line Railroad Association, consisting of annual meeting proceedings, newsletters, correspondence and traffic bulletins.

Series VI consists of real estate documents generated by the P&W and the N&W, combined and accessible by state and thereunder by town where the land was located. The series includes many documents from and to the Interstate Commerce Commission about the valuation of property owned by the railroad lines and schedules of title. Other documents include appraisals, records of land changes, reports to the ICC, and roadway completion reports.
Series VII consists of valuation and other maps of property of the P&W and N&W.

bioghist.head: Organizational history
bioghist.p: The Providence & Worcestor Railroad was incorporated in Massachusetts as the Providence and Worcester Railway on March 12, 1844, and as the Providence and Worcester Railroad in Rhode Island in May 1844. The two companies merged November 25, 1845, as the Providence and Worcester Railroad. The company bought the Blackstone Canal, also running between Providence, Rhode Island, and Worcester, Massachusetts, and began construction, partly on its banks, in 1845. The line opened in two sections, the part south of Millville on September 27, 1847, and the rest on October 20. The line from Providence to Central Falls, Rhode Island, was shared with the Boston and Providence Railroad, which at the same time built a connection from its old line (ending in East Providence) over to the Providence & Worcester Railroad.

In 1889 the Providence &Worcester Railroad was leased to the New York, Providence & Boston Railroad. On July 1, 1892, the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, better known as the New Haven Railroad, assumed that lease for 99 years. The New Haven Railroad merged into Penn Central on January 1, 1969. On April 6, 1970, the P&W announced its intention to separate from the merger. After a legal battle, the Interstate Commerce Commission approved the request on August 25, 1972, and on November 2 Penn Central signed the agreement effective December 30. The P&W cancelled the lease on February 3, 1973. Since then, the P&W has taken over many other lines from the former Penn Central and Boston and Maine Railroad and acquired trackage rights over Amtrak's shore line west of Providence. By the mid-1980s it owned over 400 miles of track in Connecticut, Rhode Island and Massachusetts.

The Norwich & Worcester Railroad was chartered in 1832 as the Boston, Norwich & New London Railroad but was consolidated in 1836 as the Norwich & Worcester Railroad. Service began on the route in 1839 and formed part of a through route between Boston and New York City. In 1843 tracks were extended six miles south from Norwich to Allyn's Point in Connecticut so that steamships could dock in ice-free waters on the Thames River during the winters. In 1869 the N&W was leased to the New York & New England Railroad, and then became part of the New Haven Railroad system in 1898. The line was extended further south to Groton, Connecticut, in 1899. Throughout the 20th century the former N&W line was used as a major exchange route with the Boston & Maine Railroad in shipping goods to northern New England. In 1969 the New Haven Railroad merged into Penn Central. In 1976 the resurrected Providence & Worcester Railroad acquired the portion of the N&W between Worcester, Massachusetts, and Plainfield, Connecticut; the remainder of the line, from Plainfield to Groton, Connecticut, came to the P&W in 1980.

The Moshassuck Valley Railroad was an independent 2-mile long short line operated between Lincoln and Pawtucket, Rhode Island, founded in 1877 to serve the textile mills between the two towns. In 1981 it was absorbed by the Providence & Worcester Railroad.

The American Short Line and Regional Railroad Association (ASLRRA), formerly known as the American Short Line Railroad Association, is an association of North American short line and regional railroads. Members include a variety of Class II and Class III railroads. The ASLRRA acts as a lobbying group for member railroads, representing them for both legislation and regulation.

did.unittitle: Series I: Providence & Worcester Railroad: Old Company
Subseries A: President's Office correspondence and bonds,
Ledger balances, works ledger, expenses ledger, and financial journal,
Correspondence regarding payroll, payroll reports, income tax documents,
Corporation income and excess profits tax documents and tax correspondence,
Series II: Providence & Worcester Railroad: New Company
Stockholder's documents, application for permission to operate independently, annual report, prospectus, minutes,
Subseries A: President's Office (documents include charters, acts to incorporate and for railroad construction, deeds, bonds and mortgages),
Subseries B: Stockholder reports and correspondence, capital stock documents and directors correspondence,

Accidents, agreements, insurance, patents, real estate, correspondence with other railroads, steamboat agreements (including "City of Lowell"), taxes, telegraph and telephone service, and provision of water,
Record of contents in vault, by-laws, mortgages, balance sheets, and authority for expenditure records,
Agreements, tax returns and income tax documents, and correspondence,
Income tax returns, insurance, and agreements with other companies,
Series V: American Short Line Railroad Association

scopecontent.p: [annual meeting proceedings, newsletters, correspondence and traffic bulletins]
